text: uh
hi everyone tooth any much tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new sufian
stevens and angelo de augustine project
a beginner's mind this is a new
collaborative album between critically
acclaimed indie folk innovator sophian
stevens and angelo de augustine a
singer-songwriter who hails from
california and has released a handful of
albums so far a few of them on steven's
asthmatic kitty label apparently this
album was also guided by a somewhat
funny conceptual process where the two
of them would watch a movie after a
day's worth of working on music and then
i guess that would inspire the themes
and writing process of the next day of
music making which is pretty interesting
and not just because this record is yet
another in a series of collaborations
that stevens has been indulging in since
the fan favorite carry in lowell in 2015
but also because the film tie-in on this
record isn't super overbearing though
there are some clear references that you
can pick up here and there if you're
paying attention wizard of oz obviously
night of the living dead as well the
sumerian shade does seem at least in
part written with an empathetic ear
toward the buffalo bill character in the
classic movie silence of the lambs
though i think also the twisted nature
of that character is explored through
the very dark and
sour ambient synth layers on the back
end of the song the jp monroe reference
on the pillar of souls makes it pretty
clear there's a hell razor nod going on
here
which
for me makes the gentle nature of
the instrumentation the singing and uh
some of the lyricism here uh so much
more hilarious especially as stevens is
singing drink the blood of my wine drink
the blood of my wine so yes the films
that augustine and stevens were watching
are very obviously influencing the
writing processes and the themes of
these tracks and you could as a listener
choose to go through this record
observing purely that and getting a lot
of entertainment out of it but
simultaneously even though works of
fiction are kind of greasing the wheels
of these tracks that doesn't stop most
of them from sounding as if they're
coming from a very personal place it
also doesn't prevent stevens and
augustine from writing about topics that
they're already very comfortable
exploring whether that be a love
spirituality mortality and tragedy also
augustine's angelic and somewhat
androgynous lead vocal is a perfect
compliment to steven's trademark hushed
quiet indie folk singing style but most
importantly the sound of this lp i think
is gonna leave a lot of fans rejoicing i
know that's the case for me as this
record is pretty much a return to the
ornate and whimsical folk music that put
stevens on the map in the first place
the opening track reach out
aesthetically and instrumentally is
classic sufi and stevens all the way to
the point where
as i'm listening to it and enjoying it
i'm thinking am i being pandered to and
if i am i i truly don't give a it
sounds so good and not to diminish a
beginner's mind as just like some rehash
or ripoff of steven's old work it's not
the writing and lyricism very much comes
from a different place and on top of it
a lot of the tracks here aren't nearly
as over the top or as extravagant as
something off of like illinois but still
the tunes are every bit as compelling
beautiful and haunting there are pockets
in the track list where augustine and
stevens do their best to give these
songs a cinematic flair which i think is
very fitting considering the concept
take for example the dramatic and
atmospheric rushes of guitar on you give
death a bad name the similarly spacious
and kind of orchestral swells of sound
on the pillar of souls give the song a
weighty quality as well but in my
opinion some of the most powerful and
memorable moments on this record are the
ones that are the quietest and most
subtle like on the title track the
simple combination of piano arpeggios
and augustine's voice
is enchanting and only more so in the
second half as we are introduced to the
super quiet and subtle weepy drones and
piano notes augustine also achieves a
high emotional intensity off of vocals
and guitar alone through much of murder
and crime which i think goes to show
when the melodies are great and the
lyrics are piercing they don't need to
be overstated they're sort of an eliot
smith type quality to the vibe of this
track too the song olympus also finds a
lot of power and simplicity as stevens
explores all of this greek mythology
which i guess was inspired by the clash
of the titans film but yeah after all
these years i think stevens has mastered
this ability to take these simple and
organic elements of vocals guitar piano
and while it comes off very intimate it
still feels so huge and wondrous then
this is the thing and it's your own body
and mind uh in my opinion have two of
the best choruses to ever end up on any
sufi and steven's record ever on the
former's opening verse where he's
reflecting so openly about people and
the human condition i think that's some
of his most poignant writing in years
too there are some velvet underground
eniko vibes on a few tracks that i liked
a lot but also took me by surprise
fictional california especially toward
the beginning or lady macbeth and chains
once that groove gets going there may be
a few tracks and spots on the lp i'm not
super crazy about like the somewhat
unceremonious closer you give death a
bad name and lost in the world i think
also features some meandering melodies
on the verses
awkward transitions into the hooks but
generally i still think these songs are
pretty listens but with all that being
said this record is great
it's great it's fantastic it's really
good it's
wonderful it's impressive it's
smart it's gorgeous it's lovely handily
my favorite thing with sufi and steven's
name on it in a while and the fact that
angelo de augustine as a singer and
lyricist impresses me just as much on
his tracks here is an added kicker a
bonus feeling a strong 8 to a light 9 on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well
and yeah over here next to my head it's
another video you can check out hit that
up or the link to subscribe to the
channel anthony fantano angelo de
augustine sufian stevens
forever
